Award.AwardTitle: 2015 Chemical Sciences & Society Summit; Leipzig, Germany - September 14-18, 2015
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award from the Division of Chemistry supports an international meeting as part of the Chemical Sciences and Society Symposia (CS3). The CS3 convenes eminent high-level researchers from the US, UK, Japan, China and Germany to explore frontier chemistry research on diverse topics. The CS3 meeting in Leipzig, Germany, September 14-18, 2015 will be on the topic "Chemistry and Water". Previous meetings have been developed multilaterally through discussions of the chemical societies in each participating country (American Chemical Society in the US). This series is intended to be of great value to the global chemistry enterprise and to the world at large as it attempts to foster work in trans-national teams, across scientific disciplines, and beyond institutional boundaries. The workshop proceedings are promoted and distributed to the global science and technology community and the general public through reports on the web.

Specifically, this workshop will focus on chemistry and its application for clean water. Four subtopics are included 1) Health and the Environment: an assessment of water and its role in disease, environmental contamination and the role of sanitation. 2) Detection: exploring analytical techniques to detect and measure contaminants. 3) Treatment: evaluating techniques to treat contaminated water including new membrane technologies, point-of-use treatment, UV, and the use of nanomaterials. 4) Recovery of Materials from Water: Assessing the viability of recovering valuable materials from wastewater including phosphorus and nitrogen.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In 2015, the American Chemical Society (ACS) was awarded a grant from the Chemistry Directorate of the National Science Foundation to lead and assist in organizing the 2015 Chemical Sciences & Society (CS3) Summit in Leipzig, Germany. The CS3 program brings together delegations from the U.S., U.K., Germany, China, and Japan to discuss frontier chemistry and how to apply local solutions to global challenges. The U.S. delegations was comprised of leaders from across the field of chemistry and chemical engineering. Matthew Platz, University of Hawaii at Hilo served chair for the U.S. delegation.

The corresponding report from the 2015 CS3 summit was released in March 2016 at the ACS National Meeting in San Diego, California. The report, "Chemistry and Water: Challenges and Solutions in a Changing World" highlighted critical issues impacting the security of our global water supply. From the September 2015 summit in Leipzig, Germany, participating delegations brought attention to four sub-areas of water which require attention from the global community. These sub-fields included: 1) Water, health, and the environment, 2) detection of chemical pollutants in water, 3) wastewater treatment, and 4) recovery of resources (namely phosphorous and nitrogen) from wastewater. The delegation provided case studies and formed the case for using chemistry to address many of these pertinent water challenges. The report was published at a critical time for the American public. As the Flint, Michigan water crisis has demonstrated, issues impacting water safety are also a challenge within the United States.

Following publication of the report, chemical societies across the United States, United Kingdom, Germany, Japan and China distributed the report to policymakers, scientific funding agencies, and other relevant water/environmental organizations for distribution and discussion. The report was picked up with interest by the International Water Association which invited speakers from the delegation speak at its Chemistry and Water forum at the World Water Congress in Brisbane, Australia. The full report of this project can be accessed at www.acs.org/cs3 .
